subsection.title: What is an Exponent?
subsection.p: The area of a rectangle is given by the formula A=lw. The variable l stands for the length of the rectangle, and w stands for for its width. The area tells us how many square tiles, one unit on a side, will fit inside the rectangle, as shown below.

Similarly, the volume of a box (measured in cubic units) is given by the formula V=lwh, where l,~w, and h stand for the length, width, and height of the box. The volume tells us how many blocks, one unit on a side, will fit inside the box. The volume of the box shown above is v=lwh = 6 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 =72~\text{cubic units}
A square is a rectangle whose length and width are equal. If we use s, for side, to stand for both the length and width of the square, its area is given by A=s \cdot s

sidebyside.p: A cube is a box whose length, width, and height are all equal, so its volume is given by V=s \cdot s \cdot s

statement.p: What is the formula for the volume of a box?

subsection.p: Finding the area of a square or the volume of a cube involves repeated multiplication by the same number. We indicate repeated multiplication with a symbol called an exponent.

assemblage.title: Expopnent
assemblage.p: An exponent is a number that appears above and to the right of a particular factor. It tells us how many times that factor occurs in the expression.
The factor to which the exponent applies is called the base, and the product is called a power of the base.

subsection.p: We read the expression 2^5 as the "fifth power of 2," or as "2 raised to the fifth power," or simply as "2 to the fifth."

assemblage.title: Exponents
assemblage.p: An exponent indicates repeated multiplication. a^n = a \cdot a \cdot a \cdot \cdots \cdot a ~~~~~~~~ (n ~ \text{factors of}~ a) where n is a positive integer.

statement.p: What does an exponent tell us?

answer.p: How many times a particular factor occurs in an expression

warning.p: Note that 3^4 does not mean 3 times 4 or 12; we already have a way to write 3(4). Remember that an exponent or power indicates repeated multiplication of the base.

subsection.title: Powers of Negative Numbers

assemblage.p: To show that a negative number is raised to a power, we enclose the negative number in parentheses.

assemblage.title: Look Closer

li.p: Only 4 is squared, and the entire expression appears within parentheses: (-4^2) = (-4 \cdot 4 )=-16

statement.p: How do we indicate that a negative number should be raised to a power?

answer.p: We enclose the negative number in parentheses.

subsection.title: Powers of Variables
subsection.p: We can also use exponents with variables. We must be careful to distinguish between a product of a variable and a power of a variable.

assemblage.p: An exponent on a variable indicates repeated multiplication, while a coefficient in front of a variable indicates repeated addition.

statement.p: Compare the expressions x^4 and 4x.

solution.p: These two expressions are not the same! x^4 \amp = x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \text{but}~~~~~~4x \amp = x+x+x+x The expressions x^4 and 4x are not equivalent; they are not equal for all values of x. (Can you think of one value of x for which they are equal?)

statement.p: What is the difference between an exponent and a coefficient?

answer.p: An exponent indicates repeated multiplication, while a coefficient indicates repeated addition.

subsection.title: Order of Operations
subsection.p: How do exponents fit into the order of operations?

statement.p: Compare the expressions 2x^3 and (2x)^3.

solution.p: The two expressions are not equivalent, as you can see by evaluating each for, say, x=\alert{5}. 2x^3 \amp =2(\alert{5}^3) = 2(125) = 250 (2x)^3\amp =(2 \cdot \alert{5})^3 = 10^3 = 1000

assemblage.p: An exponent applies only to its base, and not to any other factors in the product. If we want an exponent to apply to more than one factor, we must enclose those factors in parentheses.

assemblage.p: When we substitute a negative number for the variable, we enclose the negative number in parentheses.

statement.p:
Evaluate each expression for x=-6.
x^2
-x^2
2-x^2
(2x)^2

li.p: We replace x by \alert{-6}, and then square. This means that -6 gets squared, not just 6. Thus, x^2 = (\alert{-6})^2 = (-6)(-6) = 36 The parentheses are essential for this calculation. It would be incorrect to write x^2=-6^2=-36.
In this expression, only x is squared. The negative sign is applied to the result. -x^2=-(\alert{-6})^2 = -36

subsection.title: Like Terms
subsection.p: In Chapter 2 we learned how to add or subtract like terms. For example, 8x-3x \amp = 5x \text{but}~~~~~~8x-3y\amp ~~~~~~~~~~\text{cannot be simplified} We can also combine like powers of the same variable. For instance, 8x^2-3x^2=5x^2

assemblage.title: Look Closer

statement.p:
Combine like terms where possible.
-6a^3+10a^3
5w^2+3w^3

ol.label: a

li.p: The exponents on the two terms are the same, so they can be combined. We add the coefficients, -6+10=4, and leave the powers unchanged: -6a^3+10a^3=4a^3

ol.li: The exponents on the terms are different, so they are not like terms. They cannot be combined.

warning.p: When adding like terms, we do not add the exponents. For example, 4x^2 + 3x^2 = 7x^4 ~~~~~~~~~~\alert{\text{is incorrect!}}

statement.p: How do we combine like terms?

answer.p: We add the coefficients and leave the powers unchanged.

subsection.p: In the next Example we compare adding expressions and multiplying expressions.

Multiply: (3a)(5a)

li.p: These are like terms, so they can be combined. We add the coefficients, 3+5=8, and leave the variable unchanged: 3a+5a=8a
This product can be written as 3 \cdot a \cdot 5 \cdot a We use the commutative law to rearrange the factors and multiply to find 3 \cdot 5 \cdot a \cdot a = 15a^2
